From the moment I read an article about Glass Beach in the AAA Via magazine, I'd wanted to visit it. When my husband and I planned a trip to the area for our 30th wedding anniversary, we added this destination to our itinerary. Since we were married in December when folks aren't flocking to the shore, we had the beach pretty much to ourselves. I hadn't factored in the tides, and due to our time schedule, we weren't able to be there at low tide when more glass is visible. Even so, there was still glass to be seen on the rocky shore. We admired the sparkling show, tossed the colorful bits of glass back into the sea and spent some time snapping pictures of the beautiful coastline. This makes a nice stop when coupled with other attractions in the area, but I recommend checking the tide schedules when planning your visit.

I have read the reviews that say that the beach is completely picked over and that there is very little sea glass left. That's true if you go to beach number 3 which is the farthest beach to the north, but if you walk just a few hundred yards to the south you will see a beach that is still filled with sea glass. Here's how - from the parking lot, walk down the paved path towards the beach, once you get to the beach there is a sign that says, easiest way to the right and difficult to the left. Turn left towards the difficult direction and stay on the paved path, once you get to the first bench, cross the cable fence and walk south on the dirt path on the ocean side of the wire fence, you will see a sign that tells you not to take the sea glass and a trail that leads down the beach - you have arrived at your destination. Enjoy.

Ft. Bragg used the sea as its dump up to the 1950's and the coastal currents do not carry anything away, so unless it dissolves it stays and over the many years the broken bottles, crockery and other material have been polished by the action of sea and sand, creating tons of glass and crockery pebbles in the coves under the bluffs. Of course the easily accessible beaches have the least glass, but there are others that are harder to get to. This is particularly true since Ft. Bragg has now declared much of the area where the small beaches could be access to be closed to allow restoration of the flora and fauna, with a substantial fine for trespass. Be advised that if you can get to the water line without trespass, you can walk below the mean high tide line and pick up as much as you wish. The glass is mostly clear, brown or green, with small blue pieced available. Other colors are much rarer.

The Amount of Sea Glass Varies With Tides And Storms

Glass Beach is worth a visit anytime. There are a couple rocky coves here that were once the town dump. The amount of polished glass, ceramics and pieces of metal will vary with the level of the tide (low tide is better, lowest tides are best.) The amount is also affected by storms. Major storms can scour the treasure, long period swells can push it back up the beach. It is hard to predict and yes, the size and amount diminishes both from treasure hunters and from the action of the waves over time. The cove to the south of the access trail also has sea glass and is more difficult to climb down the trail.
For abalone divers and spear fishers: The south cove is a fair abalone picking spot at low tides and may be dive-able when the waves are too big to dive at other spots. I'm not suggesting this is always going to be a safe spot for you to dive for abalone or spear fish. When more exposed spots are not dive-able hover, the south cove at Glass Beach is slightly more protected from swells and MIGHT allow determined and experienced divers to get in the water.

Here's the DL on the Glass Beach

To anyone wanting to visit the Glass Beach, here is the review you want to read:

First off, the glass is perfectly legal to take (according to the sign and legal explanation outside the Sea Glass Museum). Still, the park rangers request that you don't take any.

Next, there is more than one glass beach. There are actually three of them; the touristy one is "site 3", that's the one that has signs leading to it, and is the easiest to find. There is plenty of surface-level sea glass here, and it's beautiful, but you really need to go in the morning during low tide. We got there at 7:30am and we had long stretches of beach to ourselves (even in the middle of June on a weekend). When we came back around 3 though, the beach was packed and it was hard to find much glass.

Site 2 is less frequently visited and has a LOT more glass; the entire beach is probably around 90% glass, and even in the afternoon we had the whole beach to ourselves most of the time. Here the glass went at least 6 inches deep. I won't tell you exactly how to get there, but it only took a bit of research online to find it. If you really want the exact location, there is a map outside the Sea Glass Museum.

I can't say much about site 1 and I didn't personally visit it. As of 2012, it was only accessible via kayak, but the new path may run next to it now. It was a dump site for longer than the other 2 sites combined, and it's harder to access, so I would imagine that it has the most glass of the 3 sites. However, according to what I've read, site 2 is the prettiest of the 3.

You have to wind through an industrial area to get to this very small beach area. We've seen rally picturesque photos of this beach and it really didn't match the expectation once on site, it is just some slightly different colored sand particles.

Just up the dirt road (by a cemetery) there is a place to walk out on the rocks (if you are adventurous) and it has some cool cutouts in the rocks that make some neat blowholes and pools.
